article.title: liquid
article.p:
liquid
, in phonetics, a consonant sound in which the tongue produces a partial closure in the mouth, resulting in a resonant, vowel-like consonant, such as English
l
and
r.
Liquids may be either syllabic or nonsyllabic;
i.e.,
they may sometimes, like vowels, act as the sound carrier in a syllable. The
r
in “father” or Czech
krk
“neck” and the
l
in “rattle” are syllabic; the
r
in “rim” and the
l
in “lock” are nonsyllabic.
